content.text:
# Grammy Award for Best Comedy Album

The Grammy Award for Best Comedy Album is presented by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences of the United States to "honor artistic achievement in comedy." The award was awarded yearly from 1959 to 1993 and then from 2004 to present day.
History
There have been several minor changes to the name of the award over this time:
*From 1959 to 1967 it was Best Comedy Performance
*From 1968 to 1991 it was known as Best Comedy Recording
*From 1992 to 1993 and from 2004 to the present day it was awarded as Best Comedy Album
In 1960 and 1961 two separate awards were presented for the best spoken and for the best musical comedy performance.
In 1994, after four consecutive years of wins by classical music comedy albums, the award was restricted to spoken word comedy albums and moved into the "spoken" field. From then through 2003, it was awarded as the Grammy Award for Best Spoken Comedy Album.
In 2004 the award was reinstated within the comedy field as the Grammy Award for Best Comedy Album, once again allowing musical comedy works to be considered.
Bill Cosby holds the record for most consecutive wins, with six earned between 1965 and 1970. Peter Schickele (of P.D.Q. Bach fame) is the runner-up, with four wins between 1990 and 1993.
Recipients
was the first recipient of the award for "The Chipmunk Song (Christmas Don't Be Late)" (1959).]]
won in 1960]]
won in 1960]]
won for The Button-Down Mind Strikes Back! in 1961]]
& Mike Nichols won in 1962]]
was nominated for his self-titled album in 1965.]]
won for "Hello Muddah, Hello Fadduh (A Letter from Camp)" in 1964.]]
holds the record of most wins in the category with seven, six of them being consecutive from 1965 to 1970.]]
won for The Devil Made Me Buy This Dress in 1971]]
won for This Is a Recording in 1972]]
won for Los Cochinos in 1974]]
won five times for FM & AM (1973), ''Jammin' in New York (1994), Brain Droppings (2001), Napalm and Silly Putty (2002), and It's Bad for Ya (2009), the last of which was posthumous.]]
won five times for That Nigger's Crazy (1975), ...Is It Something I Said? (1976), Bicentennial Nigger (1977), Rev. Du Rite (1982), and Live n the Sunset Strip (1983).]]
won twice for Let's Get Small (1978) and A Wild and Crazy Guy (1979).]]
won four times for Reality...What a Concept (1980), A Night at the Met (1988), Good Morning, Vietnam (1989), and Live on Broadway (2003).]]
won for No Respect in 1980]]
won for Comedian in 1984.]]
won for Whoopi: Original Broadway Show Recording in 1986.]]
won for Eat It (1985), Poodle Hat (2004), and Mandatory Fun (2015).]]
won for 1712 Overture and Other Musical Assaults (1990), Oedipus Tex and Other Choral Calamities (1991), WTWP Classical Talkity-Talk Radio (1992), and Music for an Awful Lot of Winds and Percussion (1993).]]
won for Crank(y) Calls in 1996]]
won for You're Good Enough, You're Smart Enough, and Doggone it, People Like You! in 1997]]
won alongside Carl Reiner for 2000 Year Old Man in 1999]]
won alongside Mel Brooks for 2000 Year Old Man in 1999.]]
won for Roll with the New (1998), Bigger & Blacker (2000), and Never Scared (2006).]]
.]]
won for The Distant Future in 2008.]]
won for The Daily Show with Jon Stewart Presents ... America: A Citizen's Guide to Democracy Inaction in 2005.]]
won for A Colbert Christmas: The Greatest Gift of All! in 2010.]]
won for Blow Your Pants Off in 2013.]]
won for Calm Down Gurrl (2014).]]
won for Black Mitzvah (2021).]]
won for Talking for Clapping (2017).]]
won thrice for Hilarious (2012), Live at Madison Square Garden (2016), and Sincerely Louis CK (2022).]]
has been nominated for and won six awards winning for The Age of Spin & Deep in the Heart of Texas (2018), Equanimity & The Bird Revelation (2019), Sticks & Stones (2020), The Closer (2023), What's In A Name? (2024), and The Dreamer'' (2025).]]
The winner is the first-named artist and work for each year, or, for 1960 and 1961, category.
